title-group.article-title: Nash Conjectures and Talent Supply in Sports League Modeling
title-group.subtitle: A Comment on Current Modeling Disagreements

article-meta.aff: 1University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA

author-notes.corresp: Rodney Fort, Sport Management, 1402 Washington Heights, Rm. 3150, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA Email: rodfort@umich.edu

fn.p: Jason Winfree is Associate Professor of Sport Management. He is the member of the Sport Management Program at the University of Michigan. His research interests include sports economics and industrial organization.

Rodney Fort is Professor of Sport Management. He is the member of the Sport Management Program at the University of Michigan. His research program examines all aspects of college and professional sports.

abstract.p: This paper attempts to resolve some of the confusion in the sports economics literature regarding conjectures, open and closed leagues, and the invariance principle in sports league modeling. Very few papers model talent level and talent investment by teams separately, which can create confusion regarding open and closed leagues. It is also important that researchers are able to differentiate between the level of talent investment a team makes and their actual talent level which depends on the type of league and the talent choices made by other teams.

disp-quote.p: At the very least, it must be the case that the underlying model on which the previous literature has relied requires a more formal justification. It may be, however, that the model just makes no sense. This has important implications not just for those interested in the pure theory of sports leagues but also for practitioners in universities and colleges who teach students the lessons of the Walrasian fixed-supply conjecture model.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Szymanski (2004) and Szymanski and Kesenne (2004) (henceforth, these authors are referred to as SK), point out shortcomings in previous modeling approaches to closed leagues (El Hodiri & Quirk, 1971; Fort & Quirk, 1995; Quirk & Fort, 1992; Vrooman, 1995; henceforth EQFV). The SK critique is that talent market models should be cast as noncooperative Nash equilibrium games and each team should be able to choose their investment in talent independent of the choices of other teams, leading to the epigram above. In addition, SK show that imposing Nash conjectures on the EQFV approach reverses one of its primary and oft cited conclusions—Rottenberg’s (1956) invariance principle no longer characterizes the equilibrium.

However, the SK model does not fully take into account additional, crucial difference between leagues with open talent market and leagues with closed talent markets. SK replaces the EQFV inelastic supply of talent condition (i.e., the condition for a closed talent market) with a condition consistent with Nash conjectures. In doing so, of course, the characterization of inelastic talent supply is lost and, in a sense, SK does not judge EQFV in the latter’s chosen market definition (on the other dimension of the competitiveness of the talent market, see Fort, 2006; Fort & Quirk, 2007). Others had also modeled conjectures in this same fashion ignoring talent elasticity (Rascher, 1997; Szymanski, 2003).

Some research subsequent to the SK critique is also confused on the open and closed market distinction. Easton and Rockerbie (2005) and Kesenne (2005) simply ignore the distinction altogether. Eckard (2006) is genuinely puzzled how the SK critique seems to force modelers to choose between inelastic supply and Nash equilibrium. Szymanski (2006) responds with an attempted restatement of the previous critique.

Vrooman (2007, 2009) models both open (elastic talent supply) and closed markets for profit maximizing teams. However, his closed league sets the sum of talent equal to a constant so he runs afoul of the SK critique by not allowing teams to make talent choices independent of each other. Similarly, Chang and Sanders (2009) discuss a league where talent is fixed but both teams in a two-team league choose talent simultaneously.

To us, all of this confusion is resolved by adding one more modeling dimension to capture both the elasticity of talent supply (the open and closed league issue) and the noncooperative Nash equilibrium context. Szymanski (2004, p. 112) actually pointed to the direction that models must take in order to accomplish this broader incorporation of Nash:
The solution to the model requires the identification of the profit-maximizing quantity of talent for each owner. This quantity translates, depending on the investment in talent by other teams, into a winning percentage, which is in turn assumed to determine revenues. (Italics added by the authors.) SK does not, however, actually take this direction and subsequent research continues to confuse this difference between talent investment and the resulting level of talent that generates wins (most recently, see Chang & Sanders, 2009 who use talent investment and the talent outcome interchangeably). This short note remedies all of the issues laid out above by adding an explicit consideration of the investment in talent. For the interchange between Eckard and Szymanski, our model shows that there need be no trade-off between closed leagues and Nash. Perhaps more importantly, our model shows that talent elasticity has implications for player pay, competitive balance, and absolute levels of talent for a league. In a closed league, a team’s talent level depends on the talent investment choices of all teams. In an open league, choosing a level of talent or a level of talent investment may be one and the same for any given team.

The note proceeds as follows. We restate the SK critique in The SK Critique section. The Investment in Talent section shows our extension to talent investment that adds the dimensionality needed to handle talent elasticity in the noncooperative Nash setting (Nash conjectures and Nash equilibrium). We also show the implications for the invariance principle. Conclusions round out the paper.

Thus, the conclusions of the SK critique in the epigram—the model “makes no sense” from the Nash perspective and the critique is important for those who “teach the lessons” of the EQFV model since one of those teachings is now reversed.

While SK make it clear that the EQFV model violates Nash, the logic of the subsequent rejection of the invariance principle in the EQFV closed league context is not clear. For, just as surely as it is true that the closed league assumption violates Nash, replacing the closed league condition with Nash conjectures, in turn, cannot be interpreted as an assessment of a closed league; one modeling dimension cannot cover two modeling issues. Confusion continues to reign on this issue as covered in the introduction. The following model introduces the added dimensionality to bring talent elasticity and Nash under the same roof.

However, regardless of any subsequent modeling treatment of the marginal product of talent investment in Equation 3, this equilibrium is no longer subject to the SK critique—it is a closed league, with Nash conjectures, and a noncooperative Nash equilibrium (both owners play their best response functions) in talent investment.

Relative to the previous literature, this result does three things. First, it answers the demands of the SK Critique stated in the epigram at the beginning of this note. If the modeler is willing to live with the implications of assuming
∂ t 1
∂ z 1
=
∂ t 2

, then there is a “more formal justification” of the EQFV model and the EQFV model “makes sense” from the perspective of the SK critique since equilibrium adheres to both Nash conjectures and Nash equilibrium. Second, adding talent investment to the model as we have done resolves the issues between Szymanski and Eckard. The modeler need not face a trade-off between the closed league and Nash. Third, as an extension to Vrooman (2007, 2009) and Chang and Sanders (2009), the model with talent investment also gets at the heart of the SK Critique, namely, Nash conjectures and Nash equilibrium in the sense of each owner plays their best response function.

Generally, nothing dictates that Equation 6 hold so it ends up that our “more formal justification” for the EQFV model need not exhibit the invariance principle. However, our model does show that if equilibrium in the talent investment market equates the marginal product of talent investment across owners, so that

Just for the sake of completeness, precisely the same line of reasoning yields the following for the open league, with Nash conjectures on talent investment, in Nash equilibrium. The invariance proposition requires: 7

.
Therefore, in the open league, the invariance principle depends on the CSF as opposed to the marginal impact of an increase in talent investment.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This paper gives a model of a sports league that allows for Nash equilibrium under both open and closed leagues, clarifying the issues underlying earlier criticisms of closed league models. In doing so, it shows that teams invest in talent in different ways depending on the type of league, closed talent market versus open talent market. Previous literature shows some confusion between the investment in talent made by teams and the team’s talent level. After all, simply because a league’s talent is fixed, the investment in talent made by teams certainly is not. Therefore, modeling should correct for the fact that talent and talent investment are not the same thing. This has implications for the invariance principle as well as many other important aspects of sports economics.

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interests with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
The authors received no financial support for the research and/or authorship of this article.
